review_title: Very poor pay and conditions but good collegiality among lower grade staff
pros: Good collaborative atmosphere within and between teams. Institution is well-integrated with the university as an academic centre.
cons: Very low pay rates at basic salary level (largely determined by central government) but also among the worst payers in the city for bank overtime shifts. Has a draconian approach to hiring non-training medical staff on very poorly-paid, outdated contracts. HR department is known for high volume of cases proceeding to employment tribunal.

pros: If you like to be busy and challenged this is the place to work,
cons: Chronic sickness within staff so always busy and challenging, never a shift with full staff

review_title: It’s fine but a bit slow

review_title: Ok place to work. Needs improvement
pros: Good colleagues. Lovely location and close to central London. Good transport links. Food places available on the main road. Good place for training.
cons: Management as always. Feeling burnt out.

pros: Working at the National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery offers the opportunity to be part of a cohesive team of SHOs, Registrars and renowned Consultants. The role offers a combination of in-patient and outpatient duties (mostly the former) and there is a robust teaching schedule which includes consultant bedside teaching, peer led teaching, journal club, Gowers and medical student teaching. A wonderful place to work and grow your knowledge base
cons: Despite the positives, this is still the NHS. Expect issues with staffing and having to jump through hoops to get annual leave approved.

pros: Professional organisation and friendly staff, center of excellence
cons: Nothing of note to say

review_title: NHS Employer who don’t support staff under management level
pros: None that I can think of
cons: Out dated processes Processes that favour Management HR does not look after under Management level staff Don’t know about how to address staff with issues like Mental Health, Stress at work, Ability to give flexible hours to help work life balance, has various isms within the work environment like racism, homophobia, bullying, misogyny, sexism, pro male environment, disabled staff being treated badly. Micromanaging and pressurising environment Values are not followed or practiced Hr and OH department are extremely bad. They don’t answer emails, and ignore questions when asked by staff. When reviewing situations it’s very one sided for UCLH and Senior Management. They are contradictory and hypocrites and not to be trusted. Even though there is a layer of what seems like support, when there is anything that requires further attention or a deeper look at it is all just a front and just first layer skin Dee.

pros: Supportive employer and good place to work
cons: Very difficult to get promotion in nhs

job_title: Clinical Trial Assistant (CTA) in London, England
pros: The salary is quite good for such an entry job
cons:
I worked within the SUMMIT study and the management team was just completely horrible. Complete lack of communication regarding serious matters. They only allowed us to work from home 2 weeks after the announcement of the 2nd lockdown. And even then, it didn't come directly from the management team, but rather through other people. They also didn't provide any equipment to allow us to carry our work from home. So I had to use my own laptop, my own printer, my own headset etc. The management team don't care about the team, especially those at lower levels then them - they rather throw at them all the work they can't be asked to do. 
Additionally, they advertised new positions externally, rather than internally, knowing that the majority of CTA team wanted the new positions.

review_title: Mixed experiences gained within two Directorates
pros:
Excellent PR
Associated with international clinical research
Brilliant, trustworthy chief nurse
CEO is from The Netherlands and active clinician concomitantly.
cons:
Staff welfare and development is variable importance in various parts of the organisation: from transparent and conducive to quality and development to directorates where micro-management, corruption and open bullying are the cornerstones of managing work. 
The biggest observable problem is task-orientedness and that firm belief of many if they do their task and the process well that yields quality (care) as opposed to striving for being person-centered and focus on the needs of staff/patients/clients.

Increasing signs of growing homophobia and discrimination based on staff members perceived ethnic roots. 

UCLH as a whole appears to ne very prone to the UK's party political games for power. In recent years this feature of 
the organisation might be digging the grave for the NHS.

job_title: Cancer Clinical Trials Unit in London, England
pros:
Team were nice people. 
Good location in central London.
Big research hospital with links to other institutions in the industry. 
High on industry radar (it seems anyway!).
cons:
Terrible communication by management.
Witnessed multiple cases of workplace bullying by one manager in particular (who the majority of staff find very unapproachable), backed up by complaints and exit interviews, yet no action taken, leading to staff feeling like senior management don't care and demoralised staff.
Management seemed to have a complete lack of empathy for staff, quite cut throat in terms of pushing the recruitment agenda but not making sure staff are supported or looked after in order to achieve high performance objectives.
Huge amounts of internal politics and favouritism.
All results in an very high turnover of staff.
Would not recommend.

review_title: Horrible bosses, a long shot at progression, the epicentre of workplace politics
pros: Decent salary, located in a nice part of the city with a big variety of food places available. The staff cafeteria isn't bad either.
cons: Outdated systems and, being a hospital, can be really stressful. To progress from one role to another takes roughly five years if you're lucky. Also, a slight hint of discrimination going on as most of the management come from the same social circles. New employees are often friends of the management who are offered jobs with no interviews made at all; they only advertise the job as policy. Managers are incompetent and don't know half of what running the hospital actually means as most of them never did the lower jobs themselves, yet they like to delegate and give orders.

pros: In UCLH, they support you whichever career path you take especially me that I am in nursing. I was in a heavy ward before but now I decided to transfer and so far I am enjoying in my new speciality now.
cons: Personally, I notice that the opportunities to level up for non British/ White people are low. This is personal only and based on mere observation.

pros:
HQ near Euston Station.
All sites relatively close to each other.
Lots of diverse and specialist services.
Some people at the top of their field and really breaking ground clinically.
cons:
Subliminal Sexism.
Completely riddled with incompetent 3rd Parties / sub-contractors who are 100 percent there to line their own pockets rather than deliver quality services and absolutely getting away with it.
Spends cash like it prints it.
Senior Management very self centred / inward looking with rose tinted glasses. 
Gross over promotion of NHS Grads in the management structure.

job_title: Senior Staff Nurse in London, England
pros:
Lots of opportunities to further your education

pros: Good to meet people & have training. I worked with a lovely team of people.

I told my managers, the senior business  partner, employee relations, the Guardians and occupational health but no one did anything to help me. I found another job and left because of this. I have since been in contact with Marcel Levi to let him know that this happened to me.
